content.text: Anthony Davis (who is really Anthony Davis, Jr.) was born and raised in South Chicago, Illinois.

content.sourceTitle: Kentucky found hidden gem in Anthony Davis
content.text: Davis is a Christian of some kind–has been his whole life. He grew up practicing basketball at a local church

and regularly attended a church in the South Chicago neighborhood of Englewood. We know this because, during the Christmas season of 2012, Davis decided he wanted to donate coats to the children of his former Chicago church. He said of the charity event:

content.sourceTitle: Anthony Davis Gives Back for the Holidays
content.text: I just wanted to give back to the city that helped me through everything. God has blessed me and with how I was raised, giving back is just a part of who I am.
We just wanted to do something for the kids in Englewood and this is the church that Anthony belongs to… ((. NBC.))

However, a  search reveals numerous churches in the area with the word "Englewood" in them, so there's no way of knowing if Davis is a Methodist, Baptist, Evangelical or what. It's safe to assume he's Christian, though. And he's at least a little devout. He retweeted:
God gave you another day to get it right! Don't take it for granted!
Obama's got jokes, Davis has a unibrow

Davis doesn't appear to be the most political person. (Actually, in the hundreds of these articles I've written, athletes tend to be mostly non-political.) But that doesn't mean politics hasn't taken notice of him.

It is well known that Barack Obama is a big basketball fan, and during a game in which Davis was playing, the president visited the locker room to shake hands with the players and joke around with Davis about his unibrow. Obama said:

content.sourceTitle: Video: President Obama jokes around with Anthony Davis
content.text: That's trademark, man, that's big money right there.

Davis is all smiles in the  and appears to be fine with the joke, so it's safe to say he's not an Obama-hater, but it's certainly far from an endorsement. Until further notice, we'll have to just call him non-political.
